commit.message:
topgit: version 0.19.13

Signed-off-by: Kyle J. McKay <mackyle@gmail.com>

README_DOCS.rst: wordsmith some of the commentary

It's not relevent _why_ Git fails (and, in this case, the analysis
either was wrong or later became wrong); what's relevant is that
Git has a major FAIL when dealing with reflogs of annotated/signed
tags.

It appears that the current excuse is that `git reflog show` being
just an alias for `git log -g --abbrev-commit --pretty=oneline` --
according to `git help reflog` -- means that anything other than a
commit cannot be handled since `git log` only deals with commits.

In any case the *WHY* is not important here, just the *FAIL* bit.
Take out the analysis (which might become incorrect in the future)
and just leave the relevant stuff.  Do add a mention of
`git reflog show` though as not everyone may be aware that it's
just an alias for `git log -g`.

Signed-off-by: Kyle J. McKay <mackyle@gmail.com>

tg-tag: handle reflog entries with extra tabs

It's very possible for a reflog entry to have more than one
tab in it.

The actual format of the reflog is one entry per line as detailed
in the `git help update-ref` documentation.

That documentation overlooks the possibility of there being more
than one "TAB" present in a single line (i.e. entry) of a reflog.

The relevant code that actually parses these lines can be found in
the Git file refs/files-backend.c in the show_one_reflog_ent function.

Behave more like the show_one_reflog_ent function when parsing
reflog entry lines to avoid any confusion over where the optional
message actually starts (if it's present).

Toggle the two affected unit tests in t6102 from `test_expect_failure`
to `test_expect_success` as they now pass with this change.

Signed-off-by: Kyle J. McKay <mackyle@gmail.com>

t6102: test tg tag -g with tabs present

Although the exact format of the reflog file lines is detailed
explicitly in `git help update-ref`, it omits any discussion of the
effect of extra tabs on the format and exactly how they are handled.

Since a tab is used as a delimiter between the committer and the
message (if the message is present), it's quite relevant.

Arrange for a whole bunch of tabs to show up in some test commits
and exercise `tg tag -g` with the resulting reflog.

Unfortunately, two of the unit tests must be marked `test_expect_failure`
at this time.

Signed-off-by: Kyle J. McKay <mackyle@gmail.com>

tg.sh: adjust use of --create-reflog option

The `--create-reflog` option first appeared in Git release 2.6.0
(commit 144c76fa39254903cb1e8e2d6d159603077356a7, "update-ref and
tag: add --create-reflog arg", 2015-07-21, v2.6.0), NOT 2.10.0
as mentioned in the topgit-0.19.12 release.

Update the test to allow the option to be used with Git 2.6.0 and
later rather than only Git 2.10.0 and later.

Signed-off-by: Kyle J. McKay <mackyle@gmail.com>

Makefile.sh: use --abbrev=8 instead of --abbrev=4

Signed-off-by: Kyle J. McKay <mackyle@gmail.com>

tg: clean up help usage output

Vastly improve the usability of the various commands'
help usage output.

Signed-off-by: Kyle J. McKay <mackyle@gmail.com>

tg.sh: handle help -h

Make `tg help -h` work just like it does for all the other
tg commands.  And `tg help --help` too.

Signed-off-by: Kyle J. McKay <mackyle@gmail.com>

tg: clean up generic help output

Vastly improve the usability of the `tg help` output.

Signed-off-by: Kyle J. McKay <mackyle@gmail.com>

various: use "command" instead of "subcommand"

Replace incorrect uses of "subcommand" with "command".

Keep "subcommand" where appropriate such as when talking about
the "subcommands" of the "tg depend" and "tg checkout" "command"s.

Signed-off-by: Kyle J. McKay <mackyle@gmail.com>

create-html-usage.pl: fuss with options indentation

When in text mode, only indent the lines following "Options:"
by 4 spaces instead of 7.

Update the two commands that currently use the "Options:" feature
to also use 4 spaces instead of 7.

Signed-off-by: Kyle J. McKay <mackyle@gmail.com>

docs: yet another alternate stub

Provide alternate stub for ChangeLog formatted documentation.

Signed-off-by: Kyle J. McKay <mackyle@gmail.com>

t2300: test tg annihilate including tg update action

Signed-off-by: Kyle J. McKay <mackyle@gmail.com>

t2200: add very basic tg depend add multiple tests

Signed-off-by: Kyle J. McKay <mackyle@gmail.com>

README_DOCS.rst: minor documentation nits

Sometimes [RELEASE] is a [BASE] sometimes it's a [STAGE].
Emphasis is like *this* not like `this`.
Refer to step (5) not step 5.

Signed-off-by: Kyle J. McKay <mackyle@gmail.com>

tg--merging: use correct first parent when fast-forwarding

Correct a long-standing error in the way fast-forwards have been
handled during octopus dependency updates.

During an octopus update, each head being merged in is checked to
see whether or not it represents a fast-forward of the initial
starting point -- if it does, the starting point is simply
fast-forwarded.

If all the heads are contained there's no problem.

Similarly, if none of the heads fast-forward there's no problem.

However, if not all the heads being merged in fast-forward and a
merge commit needs to be created, it's essential that the first
parent of the merge commit be the commit that was fast-forwarded
to and _not_ the original initial starting commit.  Otherwise the
commit that was fast-forwarded to will not be an ancestor like it
should be.  This results in all sorts of unwanted side effects
such as the remote base not being contained by the local base when
the local base fast-forwards to the remote base.

Make the trivial one-line fix to correct this and toggle the
t5021 unit test that checks this from `test_expect_failure` to
`test_expect_success` to reflect the correction.

Signed-off-by: Kyle J. McKay <mackyle@gmail.com>

t5021: test partial fast-forward dependency updates

When updating the local base and the remote branch's base
is merged in as the first dependency and that results in
a fast forward, and there's still at least one other
update to merge in that cannot fast forward; when creating
the merge commit, the first parent must not be the original
commit, it must be the commit that was fast-forwarded to.

Failure to do this correctly results in the remote base
not being contained by the local base although things seem
to work (more or less) because the remote branch contains its
remote base and when that remote branch gets merged into the
local branch that ends up pulling in the remote base changes
into the local branch, but not in proper order.

Add a new test to check for this and, unfortunately, mark
one of the unit tests `test_expect_failure` to reflect that
there's currently an unresolved problem.

Signed-off-by: Kyle J. McKay <mackyle@gmail.com>

README_DOCS.rst: expand the update process description

Include a mention of the new behavior that automatically notices
any remote-removed dependencies and skips them during the update
process.

Signed-off-by: Kyle J. McKay <mackyle@gmail.com>

tg-update: avoid updating remote-removed dependencies

When updating a branch that has a remote present, if the remote
branch has removed one or more dependencies, skip them during the
recursive dependencies update stages since they have already been
removed but that will not be reflected in the local .topdeps file
until the final step in the branch update process.

To accomplish this, simply virtually pre-merge the .topdeps file
and compare it to the local version -- if the merge succeeds,
any remote-removed dependencies are then skipped.

If the virtual pre-merge fails, that suggests that the local and
remote versions of the branch disagree about whether or not to
remove the dependency in which case it's not skipped during
recursive dependency updates and the final step in the branch
update process will produce a conflict that must then be manually
resolved.

In the future, it might be possible to resolve the conflict at
the virtual pre-merge stage and then reuse that (if rerere.enabled
is true) resolution automatically at the later stage thereby
skipping any dependencies removed by the manual merge resolution.
The current change is not yet sophisticated enough to do that.

Update the affected t5012 unit test from `test_expect_failure`
to `test_expect_success` now that it works as intended.

Signed-off-by: Kyle J. McKay <mackyle@gmail.com>

t5012: test tg update with remote .topdeps removal

When fetching updates from a remote that brings in a .topdeps file
that has had dependency lines removed (and removed properly with
the necessary "revert" patch added to the base) and simultaneously
brings in an update to one of the branches that depends on that
dependency removal, test that the local update succeeds.

Unfortunately one of the unit tests must be marked `test_expect_failure`
at this time.

Signed-off-by: Kyle J. McKay <mackyle@gmail.com>

tg-update: do not attempt to merge missing depedency

Normally all dependencies must be present in order for the
update to proceed at all.  However, if `--skip-missing` has
been given, the update can proceed with missing dependencies.

When proceeding with missing dependencies, be sure to avoid
trying to merge in dependencies that are missing to avoid
unexpected errors and premature failure for `--skip-missing`.

Update t5011 unit test from `test_expect_failure` to
`test_expect_success` now that it works properly.

Signed-off-by: Kyle J. McKay <mackyle@gmail.com>

t5011: test tg update --skip-missing

If a dependency is missing, --skip-missing should allow the update
to continue to update all the other branches.

Add tests for this.

Unfortunately, one of the unit tests must be marked `test_expect_failure`
at this time.

Signed-off-by: Kyle J. McKay <mackyle@gmail.com>

tg--merging.sh: add single file merge utility function

Add a function that emulates v_attempt_index_merge but for
only a single file.

This provides needed functionality for future enhancements.

Signed-off-by: Kyle J. McKay <mackyle@gmail.com>

tg-tag: do not update ref when dropping @{0} if different

Up until Git v2.31.0, if a reflog existed for <ref> and the
reflog is not empty, the result of `git rev-parse --verify`
for both <ref> and <ref>@{0} are guaranteed to be the same
even if the "@{0}" entry in the reflog does not match <ref>.

However, with Git version 2.31.0 and later, rev-parse will
actually return whatever's in the reflog for "@{0}" which
means it can be different from the <ref> value itself.

If `tg tag --drop` is being asked to drop <ref>@{0} and that
reflog entry does not match the value for <ref>, then do not
pass the `--updateref` argument to `git reflog delete`.

If the values are the same, continue to pass `--updateref` when
dropping "@{0}" just the same as always.

Toggle the two `test_expect_failure` unit tests in t6101 to
`test_expect_success` to reflect this change.

Signed-off-by: Kyle J. McKay <mackyle@gmail.com>

t6101: perform a few more tg tag --drop tests

When running with a version of Git where <ref> and <ref>@{0}
can be different, test the behavior of dropping <ref>@{0}
when that is the case.

Although Git version 2.31.0 or later is not specifically
required by the test, during setup and verification, if it's
not possible to create a different <ref> and <ref>@{0} value,
the later unit tests will be skipped.

Practically that means Git version 2.31.0 or later is required
for anything to actually be tested by t6101 -- earlier Git
versions will just automatically skip those tests.

Unfortunately, it also means two unit tests (when they are
actually run) are marked `test_expect_failure` due to the
current tg-tag.sh behavior in such a case.

Signed-off-by: Kyle J. McKay <mackyle@gmail.com>

t6100: compensate for Git v2.31.0+ reflog brokenness

Git reflog handling starting with v2.31.0 has fundamentally broken
behavior.  Nevertheless, it did correct one slightly broken behavior
from prior versions.

Prior to Git version 2.31.0:

  * `git rev-parse <ref>` and `git rev-parse <ref>@{0}` are guaranteed
    to have identical results even if the @{0} reflog entry does not
    actually have the same hash value in its "new" field as <ref>
    currently points to.  Except that @{0} produces an error if the
    reflog is empty or does not exist.

  * `git rev-parse <ref>@{<n>}` returns the "new" field from the reflog
    entry "n" (with the exception of @{0} which always returns the
    ref itself provided the reflog exists and is not empty -- if the
    reflog exists but is actually empty @{0} produces an error).

Starting with Git version 2.31.0:

  * `git rev-parse <ref>` and `git rev-parse <ref>@{0}` are guaranteed
    to have identical results ONLY if the "new" field from the @{0}
    reflog entry actually has the same value as <ref> currently points to.
    Except that @{0} produces an error only if the reflog does not exist.

  * `git rev-parse <ref>@{<n>}` returns the "old" field from the reflog
    entry "n-1" (with the exception of @{0} which always returns the
    "new" field from the @{0} reflog entry unless the reflog exists but
    is empty in which case it returns the current value of <ref> instead).

These are vastly divergent behaviors.  Depending on the contents of
the reflog, different answers can be produced for the same @{<n>} value
as a result and Git v2.31.0 and later can sometimes resolve one more
reflog entry (because it looks at the n-1 entry's "old" field) than prior
Git versions.

In fact, when using Git version 2.31.0 or later, viewing the reflog with,
for example, `git log --oneline -g HEAD` and then using `git rev-parse
--verify --short HEAD@{<n>}` for various values of "<n>" can result in
totally different values than were shown by the `git log -g` output,
which seems fundamentally broken.

The t6100-tag-reflog.sh test checks behavior under unusual circumstances
to make sure that `tg tag --drop` works correctly even when a reflog has
been left in a troublesome state.

As a result it must take into account the aberrant quirks of the different
Git versions in order to confirm that tg-tag.sh itself is not broken.

Modify the t6100 test to at least run "properly" under both the before and
after Git version 2.31.0 changes environment.  The previous changes to
make it work were just quick fixes that did not really take into account
the new behaviors.

Unfortunately, the t6100 test remains somewhat sensitive to any future
Git changes to reflog behavior.  In order to be sure to catch any bugs
that might crop up in tg-tag.sh that's unfortunately how it's going to
remain for the foreseeable time ahead.

Signed-off-by: Kyle J. McKay <mackyle@gmail.com>

tg-tag.sh: discard irrelevant spam when using --drop

When running a command such as:

    tg tag --drop HEAD@{3}

The 'HEAD@{3}' part needs to be validated.  When doing so, any
spam that might be emitted to STDERR such as:

    warning: Log for ref HEAD unexpectedly ended on ...

is not relevant to dropping the entry.  Git's own
`git reflog delete` operation does *not* display such spam,
therefore `tg tag --drop` should not either.

Suppress the STDERR output when checking the item about to be
dropped, but if there is a failure, then repeat the operation
to make sure that all error messages show before exiting with
a non-zero status.

Signed-off-by: Kyle J. McKay <mackyle@gmail.com>

README_DOCS.rst: tweak tg tag -g date comments

Correct the information about Git showing the actual date and time
from the reflog entry itself -- it *is* possible to get Git to show
it, but only at the expense of the index number.

It's of no significance though as that's no help with regards to
showing the reflog of an annotated/signed tag.

Signed-off-by: Kyle J. McKay <mackyle@gmail.com>

README*: minor nits and alternate stub

Title Case The Title.

Add an alternate stub suitable for turning the README into
a nice .html file with a style that matches the generated
topgit.html style.

Signed-off-by: Kyle J. McKay <mackyle@gmail.com>

README_DOCS.rst: update the out-of-date glossary entry

Correct the bit about any of the .topdeps branches not being
contained by the branch.

It's actually the branch's base that is the merge of all of the
.topdeps branches which means the branch is actually out of
date unless the branch's _base_ contains each and every branch
listed in the branch's .topdeps file.

Add the missing "base" word to the text.

Also tidy up a few bits in the area at the same time.

Signed-off-by: Kyle J. McKay <mackyle@gmail.com>
